myopenmath.statement:
Part 1 of 5
Is the variance for the amount of money, in dollars, that shoppers spend on Saturdays at the mall the same as the variance for the amount of money that shoppers spend on Sundays at the mall? Suppose that the tables below show the results of a study:
Saturday:
90.385.372.685.1136.5
106.492.968.225.842.9
80.187.181.160.738.5
71.686.157.3
(Note: The average and the standard deviation of the data are respectively 76.03 dollars and 25.678 dollars.)
Sunday:
100.9102.7107.8122.992
68.5102.683.9105.9106.6
85.969.6125.392.6108
89.297.887.9
(Note: The average and the standard deviation of the data are respectively 97.23 dollars and 15.349 dollars.)
Use a 1 significance level to test the claim that the standard deviation for the amount of money that shoppers spend on Saturday is the same as the standard deviation for the amount of money that shoppers spend on Sunday. If normality plots are not provided assume that the samples are from normal populations.
Procedure:
Two means Z Hypothesis Test
Two paired means T Hypothesis Test
Two means T (non-pooled) Hypothesis Test
Two proportions Z Hypothesis Test
Two means T (pooled) Hypothesis Test
Two variances F Hypothesis Test
Assumptions: (select everything that applies)
Normal populations
Paired samples
Population standard deviations are known
Population standard deviation are unknown
Sample sizes are both greater than 30
Simple random samples
Population standard deviation are unknown but assumed equal
The number of positive and negative responses are both greater than 10 for both samples
Independent samples

ul.li: F: Two variances F Hypothesis Test
A: Do not reject the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative.

solution.p: Is the variance for the amount of money, in dollars, that shoppers spend on Saturdays at the mall the same as the variance for the amount of money that shoppers spend on Sundays at the mall? On Saturday, the average and the standard deviation of the data are respectively 76.03 dollars and 25.678 dollars. On Sunday, the average and the standard deviation of the data are respectively 97.23 dollars and 15.349 dollars. Use a 1 significance level to test the claim that the standard deviation for the amount of money that shoppers spend on Saturday is the same as the standard deviation for the amount of money that shoppers spend on Sunday. If normality plots are not provided assume that the samples are from normal populations.

Procedure: In the question, look for the keywords such as mean/average, proportion/percentage, variance/standard deviation! In this case, we have "standard deviation for the amount of money that shoppers spend" and two populations, thus we are going to perform Two Variances F Hypothesis Test.
Assumptions (select everything that applies): For Two Variances F Hypothesis Test,

ul.li: the samples must be simple random and independent, and
for each sample, the population must be normal;
the assumption "population standard deviations are unknown" is not necessary, but since it is technically satisfied we must select it as well.

solution.p: The null hypothesis \displaystyle{H}_{{0}}: \displaystyle{\frac{{{\sigma_{{1}}^{{2}}}}}{{{\sigma_{{2}}^{{2}}}}}}={1}, where σ₁ is the standard deviation for the amount of money that shoppers spend on Saturday and σ₂ is the standard deviation for the amount of money that shoppers spend on Sunday and the units are dollars;
The alternative hypothesis \displaystyle{H}_{{a}} : \displaystyle{\frac{{{\sigma_{{1}}^{{2}}}}}{{{\sigma_{{2}}^{{2}}}}}}\ne{1} and the test is Two-Tailed

Step 3. Compute the value of the test statistic: \displaystyle{f}_{{0}}={\frac{{{{s}_{{1}}^{{2}}}}}{{{{s}_{{2}}^{{2}}}}}}=\frac{{{25.678}^{{2}}}}{{{15.349}^{{2}}}}={2.799} (Round the answer to 3 decimal places) with degrees of freedom \displaystyle{\left({d}{f}{n},{d}{f}{d}\right)}={\left({17},{17}\right)}
To practice finding the test statistic (in this case, \displaystyle{f}_{{0}}={2.799}), please consider the following problem:
Step 4. Testing Procedure: (Round the answers to 3 decimal places)

row.cell: Provide the critical value(s) for the Rejection Region:
Compute the P-value of the test statistic:
left CV is \displaystyle{f}_{{{1}-\frac{\alpha}{{2}}}}={f}_{{0.995}}={0.27} and right CV is \displaystyle{f}_{{\frac{\alpha}{{2}}}}={f}_{{0.005}}={3.707}

solution.p: To practice finding the critical values (in this case, \displaystyle{f}_{{{1}-\frac{\alpha}{{2}}}}={f}_{{0.995}}={0.27} and \displaystyle{f}_{{\frac{\alpha}{{2}}}}={f}_{{0.005}}={3.707}) and drawing the rejection region, please consider the following problem:
To practice finding the P-value (in this case, \displaystyle{2}\min{\left({P}{\left({F}{<}{f}_{{0}}\right)},{P}{\left({F}{>}{f}_{{0}}\right)}\right)}={0.041}), please consider the following problem:

row.cell: Is the test statistic \displaystyle{f}_{{0}}={2.799} in the rejection region, in other words, is \displaystyle{2.799} less than \displaystyle{0.27} or greater than \displaystyle{3.707}?
Is the P-value 0.041 less than the significance level \displaystyle\alpha, in other words, is \displaystyle{0.041}{<}{0.01}?

solution.p: Conclusion: Do not reject the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative.
At 1 significance level we DO NOT have sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative hypothesis.
(StatCrunch) In the menu, select StatVariance StatsTwo SamplesWith Summary and then enter the following:
(TI-83 Plus) Press STATTESTSD:2-SampFTest... and then enter the following:

Among the results, you can find the test statistic and the p-value. When using technology, it is much easier to conduct the test using the p-value approach. Be aware, that technology can help you with computations but you still need to be familiar with the procedure to make the right conclusion!
To practice making the decision based on the P-value, please consider the following problem:
